questions.text: Which of the following is true about hemoglobin?

choices.text: Each heme moiety can bind to two O2 molecules.
Each heme moiety consists of Iron in the ferric state.

questions.solution:
The hemoglobin tetramer is highly soluble in the plasma. However, individual globin chains are insoluble. Unpaired globin precipitates can form inclusions that damage the cell and trigger apoptosis.

Each hemoglobin molecule consists of a tetramer of globin polypeptide chains. This includes a pair of α-like chains and a pair of β-like chains. Each globin chain enfolds a single heme moiety. Heme consists of a protoporphyrin IX ring complexed with a single iron atom in the ferrous state (Fe2+). Each heme moiety can bind one O2 molecule.

The common forms of hemoglobin include:

  • HbA (α2β2): Major adult hemoglobin
  • HbF (α2γ2): Fetal hemoglobin
  • HbA2 (α2δ2): Minor adult hemoglobin

questions.text: A patient with alpha thalassemia is susceptible to which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Patients with α-thalassemia are susceptible to infection with Plasmodium vivax.

Thalassemia provides natural protection against infection with the more lethal Plasmodium falciparum. There is no conclusive evidence on the relationship between alpha thalassemia and P. malariae or P. ovale infection. 

Conditions protective against Plasmodium falciparum include:

  1. Sickle cell trait
  2. Hemoglobin C 
  3. Hemoglobin SC
  4. Hemoglobin E
  5. Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (Hb F)
  6. Alpha and beta-thalassemia
  7. Band 3 mutation
  8. G6PD deficiency 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient is given below. This abnormality is due to which of the following point mutations?

choices.text: 5th glutamic acid is replaced by valine
5th valine is replaced by glutamic acid
6th glutamic acid is replaced by valine
6th valine is replaced by glutamic acid

questions.solution:
The given image shows sickled RBCs, suggestive of sickle cell anemia. It occurs due to the replacement of the 6th glutamic acid by valine in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11. 

This mutation is due to a single nucleotide substitution (from GAG to GTG). The resulting amino acid substitution causes hydrophobic sickling of RBCs.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The features of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in fingers and toes with spontaneous resolution are suggestive of dactylitis (hand-foot syndrome), which usually occurs in sickle cell anemia.

The sickled RBCs have a sticking tendency towards the endothelium of the small venules. These abnormalities provoke unpredictable episodes of vaso-occlusion. Dactylitis is characterized by severe pain affecting the bones of the hands, feet, or both. It is often the first symptom of sickle cell anemia in children.

Treatment - Administration of patient-controlled analgesia or a frequent fixed dose of opioids with rescue doses for breakthrough pain are preferred with frequent monitoring during the initial 48-72 hrs to prevent unexpected death due to arrhythmias or pulmonary embolism.

Other manifestations include:

  • Splenic autoinfarction - repeated splenic microinfarcts 
  • Acute splenic sequestration - venous obstruction, needing emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises - vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

α-thalassemia (Option A) and β-thalassemia (Option B) are characterized by pallor, jaundice, growth failure, hepatosplenomegaly, characteristic thalassemic facies, and hair-on-end appearance of the skull.

Option D: Von Willebrand Disease is characterized by predominantly mucosal bleeding symptoms like excessive bruising and epistaxis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease?
questions.solution:
Salmonella is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis in the general population.

questions.text: What will be seen on performing hemoglobin electrophoresis in a patient with suspected sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase HbF levels?
questions.solution:
Gemcitabine is an anti-metabolite and has no effect on HbF levels.

The following drugs increase HbF levels and hence can be used in the management of sickle cell anemia:

  • Hydroxyurea - mainstay of therapy for patients with severe symptoms
  • 5-azacytidine - associated with acute toxicity and carcinogenesis
  • 5-deoxyazacytidine or decitabine - alternative with less toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following abnormal hemoglobins would be present in patients with congenital methemoglobinemia?
questions.solution:
Hb M Iwata causes congenital methemoglobinemia.

Methemoglobin is generated by oxidation of the heme iron moieties to the ferric state, causing a characteristic bluish-brown muddy color resembling cyanosis. Methemoglobin has such high oxygen affinity that virtually no oxygen is delivered. Levels >50–60% are often fatal.

Congenital methemoglobinemia arises from globin mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state (HbM Iwata) or mutations that impair the enzymes that reduce methemoglobin to hemoglobin (methemoglobin reductase, NADP diaphorase).

Acquired methemoglobinemia is caused by toxins that oxidize heme iron such as:

  • Chloroquine
  • Dapsone
  • Sulfonamides
  • Nitroglycerin

The following image shows chocolate-brown discoloration of blood in methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect in a patient with sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis is seen in sickle cell anemia, not thrombocytopenia. Laboratory findings of sickle cell anemia include:

  • Peripheral blood smear:
    • Irreversibly sickled cells (5–50% of red cells)
    • Reticulocytosis (10–25%)
    • Nucleated red blood cells
    • Howell–Jolly bodies and target cells (due to hyposplenism)
  • Granulocytosis - WBC count of 12,000–15,000/mcL
  • Reactive thrombocytosis 
  • High indirect bilirubin levels
